questions.text: Which is not true about OCT
questions.solution:
• Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) is a non-invasive imaging technique primarily used to obtain high-resolution cross-sectional images of the retina. It is especially useful for evaluating the retinal layers, detecting macular edema, and assessing the vitreoretinal interface.
  • However, standard OCT does not clearly visualize the choroidal vessels due to its limited imaging depth. To adequately delineate these deeper structures, specialized techniques such as Enhanced Depth Imaging OCT (EDI-OCT) or Swept-Source OCT are required.
  • Therefore, the statement "d. Delineate the choroidal vessels" is not true for conventional OCT.

questions.text: A newly born boy presented with leukocoria since birth. There is no family history of similar feature. The baby is not following light when examined after few weeks of birth. What is the BEST step of management
questions.solution:
Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) present at birth is most commonly due to congenital cataract, especially in the absence of a family history of retinoblastoma or other ocular conditions.

In this case:

  • The child is not following light, suggesting visual deprivation.
  • Early visual development is time-sensitive, and delays in visual input can cause severe amblyopia.

Therefore:

  • The best immediate step is to rule out cataract and, if confirmed, proceed with early cataract surgery.
  • This should ideally be done within the first 6-8 weeks of life to maximize visual outcomes.

While other conditions like retinoblastoma are part of the differential diagnosis, congenital cataract remains the most common cause of leukocoria in a neonate.

questions.text: The corneal graft can be stored in all media except
questions.solution:
Corneal grafts can be stored using several types of preservation media, depending on the duration of storage and method used.

Option D. Basal salt solution with glucose

  • Basal salt solution with glucose (like BSS or BSS Plus) is not sufficient for storing corneal grafts.
  • It lacks the necessary components (nutrients, buffers, antibiotics, and agents like dextran) to maintain corneal endothelial cell viability over time.
  • It may be used during surgery or for rinsing, but not for storage.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain and redness and vision FC close to face in OPD the next day after cataract surgery. There are cells in Anterior chamber and cornea is very hazy. Retina can't be seen but USG B scan is normal. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
This clinical picture raises concern for both acute endophthalmitis and TASS, which can look similar early on. However:

  • In TASS (Toxic Anterior Segment Syndrome):
    • Inflammation is limited to the anterior segment
    • The vitreous is not involved → B-scan remains normal
    • It presents very early (typically within 12-24 hours post-op)
    • Vision can be severely affected due to corneal edema and anterior chamber reaction
    • Pain may be present, though often milder than in endophthalmitis
  • In acute postoperative endophthalmitis:
    • Pain and vision loss are also present
    • Vitritis is typically involved (B-scan often shows echoes in vitreous)
    • B-scan might be normal in very early stages, but usually changes quickly

In this case, the normal B-scan helps rule out vitreous involvement and favors TASS as the diagnosis over endophthalmitis.

questions.text: A patient having prescription of glasses as - 2 DC at 90Deg. Which type of astigmatism it is
questions.solution:
Prescription: -2 DC at 90°

This means:

  • A -2 diopter cylindrical lens is placed at the 90° axis.
  • Cylindrical lenses work perpendicular to their axis, so this lens corrects the 180° (horizontal) meridian.

Refractive Status of Meridians:

  • Vertical meridian (90°): No correction needed → emmetropic.
  • Horizontal meridian (180°): Needs -2 D correction → myopic.

This implies:

  • One meridian is normal (emmetropic), the other is myopic → this is called Simple Myopic Astigmatism.

Rule Orientation:

  • If the vertical meridian (90°) is steeper (more myopic), it's called With-the-Rule (WTR)
  • If the horizontal meridian (180°) is steeper (more myopic), it's called Against-the-Rule (ATR)

In this case:

  • The horizontal meridian is more myopic → so it's ATR astigmatism.

Final Diagnosis:

  • Simple Myopic Astigmatism
  • Against-the-Rule (ATR)

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with RA was operated for cataract surgery one year back. She now developed decrease in vision. FFA picture showed this. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution: The fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) shows a classic bull's eye maculopathy, which is characteristic of chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine toxicity. This pattern results from damage to the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) after long-term use of these drugs, commonly prescribed for rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's history of RA and decreased vision after cataract surgery supports this diagnosis.

questions.text: A young pt with crohn's disease came with complaints of painful redness with blurred vision. She had similar episode few months back. There is no other systemic illness. What can be the most probable diagnosis looking at his picture of anterior segment
questions.solution:
B. Acute Non-Granulomatous Anterior Uveitis - Correct

  • Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease associated with HLA-B27 and non-granulomatous anterior uveitis
  • Presents with:
    • Pain
    • Redness
    • Photophobia
    • Blurred vision
    • Often recurrent
  • No granulomatous signs like:
    • Mutton-fat keratic precipitates (KPs)
    • Iris nodules (Koeppe/Bussaca)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman came with UL proptosis since few months which is painless progressive. She also suffers from dry eye. There is also HTN and hypothyroidism. What could be the most probable cause
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of painless, progressive proptosis with associated dry eye and known hypothyroidism is most consistent with Thyroid Eye Disease (TED).

While TED is typically bilateral, unilateral cases are not uncommon, especially in early or milder stages. The presence of dry eye is also a frequent finding, caused by exposure due to proptosis or associated lacrimal gland dysfunction.

Given the chronic, painless nature, lack of acute inflammatory signs, and thyroid dysfunction, the most probable diagnosis is Thyroid Eye Disease.

questions.text: What is not seen in a case of optic neuritis
questions.solution:
Optic neuritis commonly presents with:

  • Pain with eye movement (seen in the majority of cases)
  • Reduced visual acuity
  • Impaired color vision (often disproportionately worse than the reduction in visual acuity)
  • Central or paracentral scotomas
  • Relative afferent pupillary defect (in unilateral cases)

In most cases, color vision is more severely affected and tends to recover more slowly than visual acuity. This makes Option D incorrect, as it falsely states that vision (acuity) takes longer than color vision to improve, which is the opposite of what typically occurs.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man came with painful red eye since 1 day. He reports to have a gradual decrease in vision in BE since many years. On examination vision was FCCF. Cornea was edematous with a highly shallow AC. IOP was around 40 mmHg. What is the most common cause of this condition
questions.solution:
The 68-year-old patient presents with:

  • Acute painful red eye
  • Very shallow anterior chamber (AC)
  • Corneal edema
  • High intraocular pressure (~40 mmHg)
  • History of gradual vision decline in both eyes

These features are classic for Phacomorphic glaucoma, which is a form of secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by intumescent (swollen) cataractous lens. The swollen lens pushes the iris forward, leading to pupillary block and closure of the anterior chamber angle, causing a sudden rise in IOP.

questions.text: What is not true about retinal anatomy
questions.solution:
• The discs of photoreceptors, where phototransduction occurs, are located in the outer segment of rods and cones - not the inner segment.
  • The inner segment contains the cell's metabolic machinery, such as mitochondria.
  • The other statements are true: the RPE forms the outer blood-retinal barrier, the inner nuclear layer contains bipolar cell nuclei, and the photoreceptor layer consists of outer and inner segments.
  • Thus, option d is not true

questions.text: A young patient suffers from an injury by a very fast-moving blunt object on his right eye. His vision is 6/9. on examination this picture is seen. What is true about his eye condition
questions.solution:
The image shows a Vossius ring, which appears as a circular ring of pigment deposited on the anterior lens capsule. This pigment originates from the posterior pigmented epithelium of the iris and is typically seen after a blunt trauma to the eye.

  • The trauma causes the iris to be momentarily compressed against the lens, leaving a pigment imprint.
  • The ring is always smaller than the normal pupillary diameter, because it's an imprint of the pupil margin at the time of trauma.
  • It usually does not affect vision unless associated with other complications like lens damage or traumatic uveitis.

questions.text: Glaucomflecken is
questions.solution:
Glaukomflecken are small, greyish-white anterior subcapsular lens opacities seen in the setting of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

  • They result from ischemic necrosis of the lens epithelial cells due to a sudden and severe rise in intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • These opacities are a classic sign of past episodes of acute angle-closure glaucoma.
  • They are not corneal, retinal, or inflammatory in origin.

choices.text: Calcium accumulates in stroma and endothelium

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about this ocular condition where calcium is accumulated
questions.solution:
The condition described is Band-shaped keratopathy (BSK), which is characterized by calcium deposition in the superficial cornea, particularly in:

  • Bowman's layer
  • Epithelial basement membrane
  • Superficial stroma

Key Features:

  • It typically appears in the interpalpebral zone (area exposed when the eyes are open), often with a clear zone at the limbus.
  • It can occur in association with chronic uveitis, hypercalcemia, chronic kidney disease, or ocular inflammation.
  • Chelation therapy with EDTA is commonly used to remove calcium deposits.

Why Option B is Incorrect:

"Calcium accumulates in stroma and endothelium"

This is incorrect because:

  • Endothelial involvement is not characteristic of BSK.
  • The deposits are limited to the superficial cornea, not the deeper stroma or endothelium.

questions.text: What is least common finding in cases of siderosis bulbi
questions.solution:
Siderosis bulbi is an ocular condition caused by the retention of an iron-containing intraocular foreign body. The iron gradually deposits in various ocular tissues, leading to toxic changes.

Why Option D is Correct as the Least Common Finding:

Bull's eye maculopathy is not typical of siderosis bulbi.

It is most characteristically associated with:

  • Hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine toxicity (especially in patients with long-term use for conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or lupus).
  • Stargardt disease
  • Cone dystrophies

Thus, Bull's eye maculopathy is the least common among the listed options in siderosis bulbi.

questions.text: Netarsudil a new antiglaucoma drug. All are correct about this drug except
questions.solution:
Netarsudil is a Rho kinase inhibitor used as a topical treatment for glaucoma and ocular hypertension.

Mechanism of Action:

Netarsudil lowers intraocular pressure (IOP) by three mechanisms:

  1. Increasing trabecular meshwork outflow (main mechanism)
  2. Reducing episcleral venous pressure
  3. Decreasing aqueous humor production→ This confirms Option A is true

Side Effects:

  • Conjunctival hyperemia (most common)
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
  • Blurry vision→ So, Options B and C are also true

Comparison with Latanoprost:

  • Latanoprost (a prostaglandin analog) generally has a stronger IOP-lowering effect (typically 25-30% reduction).
  • Netarsudil shows a more modest IOP reduction (around 4-6 mmHg).→ Therefore, Option D is false.

questions.text: Bronze beaten appearance of retina is seen in
questions.solution:
The bronze beaten appearance of the retina is a classic description seen in Stargardt's disease, which is a form of juvenile macular dystrophy. This appearance results from the accumulation of lipofuscin in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), giving the macula a mottled, metallic look, often described as beaten bronze.

  • Best disease: Typically shows an "egg-yolk" (vitelliform) lesion.
  • Retinitis pigmentosa: Presents with bone-spicule pigmentation, not a bronze macula.
  • Sarcoidosis: Involves inflammatory ocular manifestations like granulomas, not this specific macular appearance.

questions.text: What is the MC cause of mild visual impairment in India
questions.solution:
• Uncorrected refractive errors (such as myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism) are the most common cause of mild visual impairment in India.
    • These are typically correctable with glasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery.
    • However, due to limited access to eye care, lack of awareness, or socioeconomic factors, many people remain uncorrected.
  • Cataract is indeed the leading cause of blindness (severe visual impairment), not mild visual loss.
  • Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) and glaucoma:
    • Are more common in the elderly.
    • Typically cause moderate to severe visual loss and peripheral field defects, not usually mild visual impairment in early stages.
